UK's Lee: Cats 'do care about each other'

Kentucky basketball's Marcus Lee says Wildcats have no divide over the division of minutes

Post to Facebook
CancelSend

A link has been sent to your friend's email address.

UK's Lee: Cats 'do care about each other'

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 7:14 p.m. EST December 8, 2014

Kentucky's Marcus Lee (00) and Andrew Harrison (5) celebrate during the second half of an NCAA college basketball game against Kansas, Tuesday, Nov. 18, 2014, in Indianapolis. Kentucky won 72-40. (AP Photo/Darron Cummings)(Photo: AP)

16 CONNECT 20 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

LEXINGTON, Ky. Is this the crack that becomes a divide? When Willie Cauley-Stein caught fire in Friday night's fist fight against sixth-ranked Texas and Marcus Lee was suddenly the odd man out, the one big worry for this University of Kentucky basketball team came to the forefront.

Maybe coach John Calipari can't keep 10 guys happy after all. While Cauley-Stein led the top-ranked Wildcats to victory with 21 points, 12 rebounds, five steals and three blocks in 33 minutes, Lee played a season-low four minutes and did not record a single statistic.

But a funny thing happened after the game. Calipari said Lee told him he wasn't upset, because "Willie was so good today, I accept it."

Then Sunday night, Cauley-Stein returned the favor. During a 33-point throttling of Eastern Kentucky, during which Calipari returned to (a modified version of) his two-platoon system, Cauley-Stein skipped one of his shifts.

MORE: UK's Towns "didn't want to be a freshman no more"

"Willie told Coach, 'Keep Marcus in,' " assistant John Robic said. "That's a sign of maturity. That's a sign of a leader. That's a sign of being a good teammate."

And that's a very positive sign for the Cats and their chemistry as they deal with the delicate balance between having so much talent that it overwhelms opponents and too much to keep everyone on the roster satisfied with their playing time. So far, so good.

After Friday's vanishing act, Lee had a season-high 10 points on a series of his signature sky-high dunks along with three rebounds and a block in 13 minutes. As good as it felt to get involved again, Cauley-Stein's gesture meant even more to Lee.

"Some people think we have so much talent that it's impossible to actually stay together and actually care about each other," he said. "But with this team, we actually do care about each other and hope that (teammates) do really well."

MORE: Cats crush Colonels at both ends of court

Robic said Cauley-Stein sitting so Lee could play reminded him of what star freshman Michael Kidd-Gilchrist did for Darius Miller in the 2012 SEC championship game, asking Calipari to start the senior in his place. The Cats lost that game but won the national championship, and all of them would tell you're their bond was a big reason why.

Likewise, at least outwardly, Lee is not overly concerned that his 13.8 minutes and 2.8 points per game are fewest among Kentucky's 10 platoon members. The other nine average at least 17.8 minutes and five points per game. He realizes his role is to be ready and to provide a spark whenever he's asked.

Last season's Elite Eight game against Michigan, after Cauley-Stein's season-ending injury in the previous round, is an unforgettable example of that. He scored 10 points more than his previous 15 games combined in 15 minutes off the bench to help the Cats reach the Final Four.

Video | Marcus Lee previews No. 1 Kentucky's opener

Sunday's performance reminded teammate Karl-Anthony Towns of that game back in March.

"So proud of my brother," Towns said. "Spent so much time, just me and him alone, just talking, building everything up and also just (letting him know) he has a lot of game. A lot of game. He just has to show it all the time. I think (Sunday) was a great example of what he definitely can bring to the table."

Maybe more importantly for Kentucky, though, is what Lee doesn't bring: a bad attitude about playing time.

"We get lost in our own team. I think that's what makes it really easy," he said. "You'll see our players on the bench laughing, getting hyped, jumping up and down if something happens on the floor. It's just great that we're so into each other instead of ourselves.

"Willie was killing it the other day. Sometimes Willies going to have a great game, and you just be like, 'OK, Willie, you're having a great game. Stay in.' "

Kyle Tucker can be reached at (502) 582-4361. Follow him on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ.
